title: 'Band of Brothers' paratrooper Edward Tipper dies at 95
text:
'Band of Brothers' paratrooper Edward Tipper dies at 95 Edward Tipper Hyoung Chang / AP Edward Tipper is honored in 2011 during a program hosted by The Greatest Generations Foundation in Denver. Edward Tipper is honored in 2011 during a program hosted by The Greatest Generations Foundation in Denver. (Hyoung Chang / AP) Associated Press 
Edward Tipper, a World War II paratrooper who was portrayed in the HBO mini-series "Band of Brothers," has died at the age of 95. 
He died Feb. 1 in the Denver suburb of Lakewood, his daughter said. 
Tipper was a member of the famed Easy Company, part of the 101st Airborne Division, and parachuted into France as part of the June 6, 1944, Allied D-day invasion. 
The company's exploits were retold in "Band of Brothers," based on research by historian Stephen Ambrose. 
Ambrose died of cancer Saturday in Helena, Mont., his sister Stephenie Ambrose Tubbs said Tuesday. ... Read the story 
Tipper was interviewed for the series and was portrayed by actor Bart Ruspoli. 
A few days after the parachute drop, Tripper's eye and leg were badly injured by a mortar shell and he was hospitalized for a year. 
Tipper was awarded the Bronze Star and Purple Heart. 
Doctors gave him a list of things he couldn't do, but that became his checklist for things to master, his daughter said. 
"He was defiant above all," Kerry Tipper, his daughter, told The Denver Post. 
He took up handball, not because he liked it, but to prove he could do it, she said. 
He was also an avid skier and kept that up into his 80s, she said. A promotional shot for the 10-part HBO series "Band of Brothers." David James / HBO A promotional shot for the 10-part HBO series "Band of Brothers." A promotional shot for the 10-part HBO series "Band of Brothers." (David James / HBO) 
After the war, Tipper attended the University of Michigan and the University of Northern Colorado — then the Colorado State College of Education — and became a teacher. 
His first teaching job was in Iowa, and then he returned to Colorado, teaching English and literature and running drama programs in Jefferson County on Denver's western edge. 
"So much of what people talk about with him is what he did in the war. That was two years and really six days starting on D-day," Kerry Tipper said. "Teaching was 30 years." Caption 90 seconds: 4 stories you can't miss
